awd_titl_txt: E2CDA: Type I: Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a critical need for new technologies as the semiconductor industry reaches the limits of how small a transistor can be made and how much power can be used in an increasingly small space. This project will meet this need through the development of novel memory and logic devices. Continual interaction between academia and the semiconductor industry will ensure in new semiconductor device concepts that lead to faster and better electronics that use significantly less energy than current approaches. These advances will exploit the unusual magnetic properties of magnetoelectrics, a special class of materials that tie together magnetism and voltage. An important aspect of the devices will be their nonvolatility, a feature that makes them prime candidates for use in the emerging Internet of Things. Nonvolatility refers to the property that once written, information can be recovered, even if electrical power has been absent for an extended period. An example of such a situation is the shutdown of a computer. A computer equipped with this type of "instant on" circuitry will restart to the exact state when power failed. Nonvolatility will also lead to energy savings by enabling electronics to operate longer on smaller batteries with less need for recharge. Reducing the energy cost of consumer electronics could also lead to some world-wide energy savings, as new less energy expensive electronics become available.

This project develops novel device concepts to greatly extend the practical limits of energy-efficient computation, focusing primarily on magnetoelectric materials, enabling interfacial magnetism to be reversibly switched by voltage. This approach to the writing of magnetic information via voltage will result in a significant reduction in energy consumption, while improving the computing speed of integrated circuit technologies. To enable electronic applications based on these devices to come to fruition, the new concepts must allow for miniaturization, inexpensive fabrication on a huge scale, and long working lifetimes. Just as for conventional electronic circuits, to ensure reliable operations, the new devices will be capable of operating repeatedly at well above room temperature. By exploiting more than just electrical charge in each device, these new devices will have more function than a simple transistor, which in turn, will present new opportunities for the development of circuit ideas that go beyond existing technologies ? ideas that will also be explored as this research program develops.

por.por_cntn:
The Center Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic (AMML) has focused on developing novel device concepts based on the voltage control of interfacial magnetism - the physics that is exploited is called the magneto-electric effect. The premise is that electronic devices based on these concepts will greatly extend the practical limits for energy-efficient computation. The paradigm proposed by this team of nine investigators from across five universities are some device concepts that could move electronics and computing beyond the technology of silicon. These device concepts could potentially lead to significant energy savings. Big computers with lots of data storage memory and computing power consume a lot of energy, but so does all sorts of electronics in toys, phones, game stations. If electronics could be redesigned to be much more simple, still achieve the function, perhaps even be able to do bigger computations, require less programming, retain a lot more data and yet cost less energy, this would be significant. Better electronics that does more and yet uses less energy would be a significant advance for all of society.

      The general approach of the Center Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic has been to exploit the interface in materials with "switchable" interface properties. In other words, the idea is to exploit materials that are not ferromagnetic, BUT where the surface has unusual properties that can be controlled by voltage alone. What was sought were materials combinations where a voltage could influence the spin and charge of the current driven through the device. This is spintronics without ferromagnetism. Using a fairly basic material, chromia (a very stable oxide of chromium metal), center has shown that in fact such devices can be made where voltage can be used to control magnetism. In fact, several very different types of working devices have been constructed. An example is shown. What is truly great about these demonstration devices is that these working devices require no power and no voltage to retain memory of their operational state meaning that every device can be placed in an "on" or "off" though might be better described as "up" or "down". This would be like losing power to your computer, then turning your computer back on and the computer 'remembers' exactly what was happening when it was unplugged - no loss of data and no loss of memory. This retention of state, without the need for power, means that far fewer device elements must be combined than would be need in traditional silicon technology to achieve the same 'computing' result.

      Not only have working magneto-electric (voltage controlled spin and charge) device been demonstrated but the device work at room temperature and all the way to the temperature of boiling water. Semiconductor materials have been developed by the Center Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic that can be used to make a transistor 10 to 20 atoms wide. This is much smaller than any silicon transistor. Devices that respond to light and are sensitive to all sort of properties of light, like color, were also fabricated and characterized.

            While much has been accomplished in the 4 years of the Center Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic, much remains to be done. Further work is needed to demonstrate that the concept devices of Center Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic are in fact faster and can be made smaller that silicon technology. While it might be some time until these new devices are used to replace computing with silicon technology it is clear that these concepts can be used to build digital memory that can be written and very fast speeds, and the information stored can be read at even faster speeds. This technology is simpler, faster, better and costs less energy than the traditional silicon technology used for data storage. The team of the Center Antiferromagnetic Magneto-electric Memory and Logic has built a road map of how even more successful magneto-electric devices might be built and implemented.
